enclosed litter box for 1 cat fine?

for my living/dining room area which is near my outside door (tiny 
apartment). Would an enclosed box be fine there?

leave the top off the outer box (it would have an open litter box inside 
it).
I have 1 cat and he goes pretty much wherever he wants in my home, however 
I'd rather not piss off the landlords.﻿
top_comment.author: crazycatlady39

comments.text:
+Wendalore65
No
Cats have a sense of smell that is many times stronger than ours.
Enclosed litter boxes get very smelly to us, so imagine what it is like for 
them. They will eventually stop using the box because the smell is so 
putrid. 
A normal, large litter box should be fine for your cat, +crazycatlady39 but 
if you are worried about something getting on walls/carpet then I would 
suggest that you make a corner waterproof. Using something like a floor 
protector for a desk chair would be ideal for under the box. If you use 
tarp or something loud or strange feeling to the cat, he won't like it and 
will not use the box. A tarp/rubber sheet hung on the walls surrounding the 
box will prevent anything from going on the walls. It's important that 
you're also reinforcing his good behaviour (using the litter boxes) by 
small treats, petting etc and deterring him from bad behaviour like yelling 
"no", spraying him with water (nothing else). When you do see him not using 
the litter box, pick him up (ew I know) and place him in the box. When he 
tries to leave without using it, keep him there until he does.
comments.author: Emilia Kills

comments.text:
You need to take her to a vet immediately. It sounds as though she is in 
pain, so whether it's arthritis or something else going on in there, you 
need to find out and help her. It's likely your cat has some pain like 
arthritis or the litter box isn't meeting the requirements she needs.
I notice you said you have "a" litter box with a hood. As Jackson is 
constantly telling his viewers, 1 tray per cat and then always an 
additional one! The hooded boxes are a bad idea. Your cat is not going to 
like it and she will resort to not using it eventually because she too, 
will be bothered by the smell. If she has an issue with squatting like pain 
then you need to put the litterboxes in a place that is waterproof, like 
somewhere with tiles. No hoods.  
Take her to the vet immediately.
Get TWO uncovered litterboxes - if needed, place them in a waterproof area.
Make sure that her "smell" is around the rest of the house - rub blankets 
she sleeps on etc on the walls of the house. Make sure she has at least two 
scratching posts placed around the house. If this is a territorial issue 
then this will help.

comments.author: Lewlew066

comments.text:
I think that the key is understanding the principle behind JG's guidance. 
 Each cat and household is different. I see 2 main principles here to make 
things work for kitty and human:  LOCATION & LITTER TYPE.     LOCATION:  I 
don't think the box has to be the focal point of the living room.  I only 
have 1 cat and she is my first so my experience may be limited compared to 
others.  We only have 1 litter box.  Previously, she had the guest bedroom 
(no, not enclosed -- she had the run of the apt) and her litter box was in 
the en-suite shower stall.  It was a glassed stall with an open glass door, 
so she would't have felt closed in.  When we were moving, I stayed with my 
sister and her litter box was next to my bed.  Now we are in a tiny apt and 
her litter box is in the bathroom, next to my own "litter box", so to 
speak. When we move back to our permanent townhouse home, there will be 3 
floors.  I don't plan to put a box in the living or dining room, but I do 
plan to have more than one box -likely one on the entry level and one on 
the 3rd, bedroom floor, avoiding the living/dining/kitchen floor all 
together.  The main thing is for my kitty 1) not to have to go TOO far to 
get where she needs to go.  ie/ not have to climb or go down 2 floors;  and 
2) not to be in some scary, dark or dirty place like next to the furnace or 
in a cobwebbed, damp corner of a basement.  If she would start to have 
mobility problems so that doing stairs is always difficult or painful, I 
would, for sure, put a 3rd box on the 2nd living/dining floor, likely in 
the kitchen.  LITTER:  it is worthwhile spending more on a quality litter. 
 I had to use a scented clay litter when we first arrived in this tiny apt. 
 The dust would eventually waft into the living/kitchen area, which I 
hated.  The scented litter was evident when passing the bathroom door.   I 
was later able to get my corn-husk-based litter.  what a relief!  Almost no 
dust and I chose the unscented kind.  I clean the box morning, after work 
and before bed.  I use a small plastic pail like a diaper pail and the used 
litter goes in a plastic bag, twisted closed and into the pail until i'm 
ready to make the trek to the outside garbage.  There is no smell at all, 
no dust invading my living space.  This experience between the 2 types of 
litter makes me feel that the extra I spent on the better litter (World's 
Best) was very well spent.  I must admit that there is one more aspect to 
my litter-box satisfaction - I note that there are all kinds of litter 
scoops out there.  I have more than one type.  However, the best, I find, 
is an old spoon.  Instead of breaking up the clumps by pushing through with 
a litter scoop, I locate them, "excavate" a little and can pick up the 
whole clump with very little breaking -- super easy with World's Best. 
 With very little soiled litter left behind, the litter is clean for weeks 
and doesn't smell.

CONCLUSION:  just like we wouldn't go to the bathroom in our living or 
dining rooms, I don't think kitty has to either (unless you are trying to 
correct a territory- or confidence-related behaviour problem -- you might 
have to do this at first). However, just like us, she doesn't want to have 
to make a long trek when Nature calls and she doesn't want to do it in some 
enclosed, dark or dirty corner.  A good quality litter and regular cleaning 
regime can improve the quality of life you and your kitty share.  I think, 
therefore, that there are lots of options for litter box location in a 
home.  It's good, like someone else said, to think about the changes 
necessary before sharing one's life with a cat(s).  However, I think Yapple 
Dapple has options and may be ok with a cat after all -- or maybe not, 
after all. A cat is a live creature with emotions and physical and 
psychological needs and cannot be contained like a plant so,yes, do think 
about it.  But a plant isn't nearly as much fun or as fulfilling!  With 
education, thought, research and experimentation, it can/can work.
comments.author: Chipmunk Chipmunk

top_comment.author: Kati Volk

comments.text:
Very strange. Did you have him since he was a kitten or adopted him as an 
adult?
If he was adopted in adulthood, it may be that he was previously trained to 
use the toilet and is now using toilet/toiletlike places to go. The way 
that cats are trained this way is by using a kitty litter tray that is 
specifically shaped to fit on the toilet, eventually through stages the cat 
learns to use a toilet.
I suggest retraining him in this way as well as having a normal litter tray 
around the house. What you are doing with the water in the sink is good as 
it is obviously deterring him. You don't have a problem with it but guests, 
future kids etc will find it unsanitary, whether you keep it clean or not.

comments.author: 923rememberme

comments.text:
Unfortunately there's a strong chance that the cat has an untreated UTI or 
similar which is going untreated. You can always try hiding a secret litter 
box you maintain like the other poster said, or "gift" her an extra litter 
box that "just happened to come your way" to spread out the options in 
between cleaning. Placement matters too, which you don't really have much 
control of, such as avoiding laundry machines - one of our older cats used 
to pee on the couch and it drove us crazy until we realized she only did it 
when she needed to pee and someone was running the laundry and it scared 
her. Recently she started peeing all over again, and she went to the vet 
and turns out she has asthma and every time she tried to use her (very 
dusty) litter she'd get an asthma attack. Changed the litter to a non-dusty 
brand and problem solved.

top_comment.text:
I use a big litter box with a hood because my little cat seems to think 
that she must work extra hard to cover up what she did in there.  Before I 
got the hooded box, there was a lot of litter thrown out of the box all 
over the place.  If I fill the box more than 3" deep, she just has a good 
ol' time and there is even more litter that gets thrown.  I use a 
scoopable, flushable cat litter and scoop it out daily.  I tried 2 
different really deep litter boxes before I got the hooded one, hoping the 
litter would stay inside.  It didn't.  

I chose the hooded litter box that was a pearl white color so light can get 
through it in case she did not want to go in a dark place. (It's like the 
big round one in the video with a little stairway that does not have its 
hood.)  I doubt if the color really matters, but it was just my gut 
feeling.  It's big enough for her to poop on one side and pee on the other. 
 

Maybe if there were a problem with her going outside of the litter box, I 
would consider getting another.  As long as they are kept clean, three 
litter boxes for one cat just seems like overkill to me.  I wouldn't go 
scattering litter boxes all over my living space unless I found it 
necessary.   

So, the hood has nothing to do with my aesthetic preferences.  Just sayin'.﻿

comments.text:
+Wendalore65 Happy Thanksgiving to you too!  I agree with what you say.  If 
we are going to get a pet or more, we also must take the responsibility

dependent on their humans than cats are.  Cats seem to want to make sure we 
know that too with some of their attitudes. ;-)  

I love animals, but I think cats are best for me. In particular one cat at 
a time, because I am the only human living in a small apartment.  Cats are 
so territorial and usually gravitate to one human when there is more than 
one in their living quarters.  Mostly all we need to do is give them what 
they naturally need when they are house cats.  

I think this guy is just doing his best to educate people that there is a 
big responsibility to properly have cats living with you.  

Mine is jealous of my laptop.  She is usually in my lap when I'm using my 
laptop, which sits on the arm of my recliner.  She will gnaw a little on 
its corner or place her paw on a couple keys when she wants petted.  She 
always manages to hit the caps lock key and I ask her if she wants to 
"yell" at someone - haha!  My little kitty is for sure a companion in my 
life for whom I am thankful everyday.  I especially recognize her as one of 
my many blessings on this Thanksgiving day.
comments.author: creativeplanetjanet

comments.text:
+creativeplanetjanet Hi! nice to get your email this Thanksgiving Day! Yes, 
I see what you mean, the more litter boxes you have the more litter boxes 
you have to scoop! As far as him "letter the cats rule the house," I think 
there is a subtle difference between "cats ruling the house" and "going out 
of your way to make the cat happy and secure." I'll give two examples to 
demonstrate. 1. Letting cats rule the house (and you) is doing whatever 
they indicate that they want you to do for them every single time they 
"ask" for it. Claire Bressant (The Cat Whisperer) gives examples of older 
cats who become insecure in the night and howl. (it seems that in England, 
they generally shut their cats outside their bedrooms.) So the older cat 
howls and howls and the owner gets up EVERY TIME it feels lonely in the 
night. That is an example of letting the cat rule you. Or feeding the cat 
every time it asks for food. One of my daughters did that and she always 
would up with very fat cats. So, doing what the cat fancies every time it 
demands it is often not even GOOD for the cat.  As you say WE are their 
masters and WE know best (when we do!!)  2/ Going out of your way to 
provide conditions that make the cat happy and secure. Here's an example of 
that. A cat owner complains that their cat scratches up the furniture and 
the rug every day. No matter how many times they punish the cat, it keeps 
doing it.  Plus it is peeing on the rug beside your favorite chair, which 
is shredded by now. YOU probably already know the solution to this!  The 
cat has genetic NEEDS, that it evolved in the wild, and one of them is to 
do this scratching thing. It allows the husks of the old claw to fall off, 
and it exercises many of the muscles in the back and legs, releases energy, 
thus relaxing the cat, and provides pleasure for it, just like exercising 
does for humans.  So the solution comes from CATegory number 2, providing a 
little extra for the cat. The result is good for the cat AND good for us!! 
The owner provides some scratching posts, depending on the size of the 
house, (with retraining, you might need more than usual) and the cat soon 
is using the scratching posts and not the furniture and the rug. The owner 
is happy, the cat is happy and more healthy. And the relationship between 
the cat and the owner is improved!!  So, are we letting the cat rule us by 
buying scratching posts for it?   I think the issue boils down to whether 
the CAT is ruling us or whether the cat's NEEDS are guiding our behavior.  
Because if we don't satisfy the cat's needs, we are going to pay for that 
by having to put up with the cat's bad behavior. Examples of cat's bad 
behavior resulting from needs not being met can be seen on "My Cat From 
Hell."  Not that anyone is to BLAME. We are just ignorant of what the cat's 
needs ARE. And that is what Jackson is trying to teach everyone.  Examples 
of cats needs: "Property" of its "own." "Vertical Space." (cat trees) Space 
just for cats that runs around the upper part of the room ("cat 
super-highways," cat shelves placed so the cat can jump from one to 
another, no cat flaps to the outside, b/c the cat knows its rivals can come 
in that door, enclosed places for it to sleep, for security and warmth, 
(small circular beds with sides) Cat toys to play with, on his own, and 
controlled by you, like a toy bird on a string, or "fishing rod" type set 
up, and play with the cat vigorously frequently, times for cuddling in your 
lap, if the cat likes it, and stroking, and cat signals, like the slow 
blink to show your love, and communication, and do not shut the cat away 
from you much, and when you go on a trip, leave fabric with your scent on 
it, to help them be secure. Do not clearly favor another cat. And if you 
WANT, you can double the amount of cat furniture, toys etc. And of course, 
proper food and proper litter boxes. See, the cat DOES NOT KNOW that you 
are going out of your way to provide these—what you might think—are extra 
things. Therefore it's not the CAT that is ruling us.  It's the cat's 
needs.  When we don't take care of the cats' needs, they become anxious and 
insecure, and they act out their anxiety by doing things that it knows are 
outside its routine.  THAT I'd like to learn more about.  And back to 
number 1, the CAT ruling us—that is just all those demands the cat makes on 
us that it really doesn't need, it just would like to have. I just 
remembered the old saying, "A door is something that a cat wants to be on 
the other side of!" There is cat behavior in which the cat is ruling the 
human!  I would say allowing a cat to scratch you in play is one of those 
cat-rulling-you behaviors. Feeding it every time it asks, also, and letting 
it lie down on your computer keys, so that you stop working every time it 
demands that you do is another. Cats will not BE better off if you allow it 
to rule you. Hey, I wonder if it's like children. They NEED to know their 
boundaries!!  Well, as usual, I've had to write three times as much as 
everyone else to explain my points!!  What do you think? Is it worth it? or 
does it get boring?
AND THEN of course, there is the matter of—if you get an animal, are you 
going to provide what it needs so that it will live comfortable with you 
and not a pest that you would like the get rid of?  I think one of Jackson 
Galaxy's goals is to educate humans enough so that they'll know in advance 
what taking care of a cat entails, so that you know whether you are willing 
to devote the time, money and LOVE to it!
comments.author: Wendalore65

comments.text:
To bharathy reddy re biting cords: I've had good luck with a few different 
solutions.
# 1 is tabasco sauce (probably any hot sauce). Put a tiny amount on cat's 
lips — best done when you catch kitty in the act of cord chewing, and just 
once should be enough to instill aversion — and then dot the cords w/ 
tabasco. A slight whiff will remind them of the unpleasantness. (The 
'pretreatment' seems cruel, but works better than just peppering the cord, 
and it may save kitty from much worse than a single experience of hot lips.)
#2: Another set of cords was irresistable to one kitten (who apparently 
likes spicy food) so I placed the whole 'tangle' inside a pillowcase until 
she grew up.
#3 is plastic tubing. Get a few yards of flexible tubing from a hardware 
store (many types available), slit it all along one side and push the cord 
inside it for an extra protective layer. (Since only a few inches of my 
Dust Buster cord is exposed to cats, I just encased it in a tube from an 
e-cigarette.) I guess kitties don't enjoy the tubing  — not as chewy as the 
cord — and now just leave cords alone.
comments.author: Lucia Benyova

comments.text: well I will awnser #2 mix them! :)

comments.text:
Re the food issue. Males seem to do better with a higher proportion of wet 
to dry and females the opposite. Buying good quality food really is the 
answer full stop. My female cat thrives on the Purina One dry food with one 
pouch of Felix a day. I've had other cats who preferred Science Diet. None 
of my cats ever liked Whiskas for some reason, some liked Gourmet Gold Pate 
and others not. It's usually a case of trial and error for a while till you 
find the right balance for your cat. If they don't like it they won't eat 
it regardless.

comments.text:
+Gingerjake2
oh and, if you teach your cats to only eat twice a day, you will see that 
they will start peeing and pooping almost at the same hours. They will cry 
at first for food if they don't have it in their faces always, but try to 
feed them some time after you wake up, maybe half or even an hour after you 
wake and then an hour or 2 before you go to bed and they will go, like a 
clock, to the bathroom in the morning and evenings and this also makes it 
easier for you to clean the tub/shower/sink. My baby's timetable :)) : eat 
at 8 am, eat at 8-9 pm and pee and poop at about 7 am, pee one more time 
around 1 pm then pee at about 10-11 in the evening. The timetable usually 
varies by half an hour sooner or later. When my other 2 cats were alive, 
they had the same schedule. Food and tub took about 2 weeks to turn this 
into a habit and you can adjust it to your schedule.

I love my pets and I am glad we found a way to coexist with no litter :D
comments.author: Cristina Sburlea

comments.text:
+Gingerjake2 Well one of my cats also tried to pee in the toilet. But, by 
the time I noticed it and went toward the bathroom, she was already falling 
into the toilet. That was funny to watch, but not as funny when I had to 
give her a bath right after that. The way I taught my first 2 cats to pee 
in the tub is to place a bit of litter next to the drain (just a tiny 
amount) and after some time after they finished eating (they eat wet food 
and raw meat so they get plenty of hydration), I picked them up and put 
them in the tub, showed them the drain and with my fingers I moved the 
litter around a bit and then I left them there with the door closed (not 2 
cats in the same bathroom. well they can be in the same bathroom if you 
allow the other to use either the sink or a shower cabin if you have one) 
until they peed or pooped. After that, they instinctively went back.

I did keep a close eye on them for the first 2 days, just to make sure 
there was no "accident". I also cleaned immediately after I noticed they 
peed/pooped because if it is kept clean, they will be encouraged to go 
back. A few days later, it did not matter if I did not clean immediately 
and they had to pee or poop cause they just moved to the other side of the 
drain. I tend to clean right after cause I hear the noises of the claws on 
the tub. They will try to use the tub as if it is a litter box so, even if 
it has no litter, they will still try to bury their feces. I always check 
the tub when I get into the bathroom for whatever reason. But you don't 
have to check cause as we all know, it stinks when they pee/poop :)) so 
you'll know when something is up.

So, I decreased the amount of litter every day until there was no more 
litter next to the drain and now I have a house completely free of litter. 
With my third cat I did not even had to keep her in the bathroom when I was 
estimating she had to pee. Right after I got her home, knowing that she 
would get nervous when she would have to go, I just had my eyes on her a 
bit more and when I thought she would have to pee I picked her up and 
placed her in the tub and she did there what she needed to do. She had just 
one accident probably the next week but she was still a baby and it is 
harder for them to control their bladder. Now, 6 months later, if I am in 
the tub, she will just wait for me to finish washing, then I dry the tub 
and she gets in. So try to keep your tub dry (though they will go straight 
in, no matter what, if they need to go), use something to disinfect (I 
don't recommend chlorine because of the scent and toxicity for them. Mix 
apple vinegar with water and spray then wipe or use any other cleaning 
product that does not have chlorine), pick up the poop with some toilet 
paper and throw it into the toilet.

I know I wrote a looong comment, but it does not take that much to get them 
used to this. I was still a kid when I first did this soo it is not the 
most difficult thing in the world. Also, use a bag of the cheapest litter, 
you don't need anything fancy to get them used to this (it might be 
recommended that you change the litter you already use as they seem to not 
like it) you need something that is odorless and you will probably end up 
throwing away most of it anyway. And, if possible, allow them to have 
separate drains to use ;)

I adopted 2 kittens and an adult cat and fostered 5 kittens and adult cats 
in 15 years and this always worked. Some were a bit more stubborn, but it 
gave results in a few days.
comments.author: Cristina Sburlea

comments.text:
+procrastistamper Lol! I often have the 'I wish vets made house calls'

comments.author: Keara Osborne

comments.text:
+Keara Osborne Sure sounds like you're doing the right things! Two other 
ideas are: 1) maybe the separation was not long enough before 
reintroduction, or the reintroduction may have advanced more quickly than 
your cats needed, and 2) it's possible the smells were not fully removed 
from the territorial areas, and the cats went back to the same old habits 
when triggered by the same old smells. Maybe try a black light, and that 
Frizzion spray for clean up at the same time you do the separation. Best of 
luck...I still have issues here because my cat #1 is 13 years old now and 
never fixed, because she is impossible to catch and get in a carrier to 
take to the vet, and because she's such a runt/fraidy cat that I am afraid 
if we did take her in to get fixed, she would die from traumatic stress. 
:-(  I wish there was some kind of kitty valium we could give her, but she 
also refuses to eat food that has other stuff in it, so that won't work, 
either! Maybe if there were vets that could do house calls for fixing pets 
(using a tranquilizer gun or something to catch them), we could get it 
done. Lol.
comments.author: procrastistamper

comments.text:
+procrastistamper I like that idea so much, I've already tried it - even 
using the exact precious cat and spirit essences products you listed! Which 
makes me feel a little less crazy. I'm going to try it again, I think. 

I followed the Spirit Essences ultimate peacemaker (I think that's what 
it's called, the 3 pack combo) directions to the letter for 8 weeks and had 
some luck with cat #1, but saw no change with cat #2. I've kept Self Esteem 
up with cat #1, but I think it might be worth trying the whole process 
again. I'm going to just start that whole process over, I'm sure I did 
something wrong last time.
comments.author: Keara Osborne

comments.text:
+Keara Osborne I have an idea, but you probably need to get both kitties to 
a good vet first to rule out other issues. You may not like this idea, but 
you might want to separate the cats entirely into their own living spaces 
for a while, get them all new litter (recommend Dr. Elsey's Cat Attract at 
first, then his Precious Cat for later) and boxes (so there is no odor 
introduced but their own), and leave them in their own spaces to use their 
own boxes for a while. Then, just gradually reintroduce them according to 
Jackson's protocol. Leave their own litter boxes in their own separate 
spaces even after reintroducing, and maybe incorporate the third one as a 
completely new/clean one at the same time you reintroduce them. (maybe even 
scoop a poo from each kitty's separate box and put it into the third one 
together?? then no one gets to put their own scent in there and "claim" it 
first!) Also, the Spirit Essences helped in my home: Bully Remedy for cat 
#2, Self-Esteem for cat #1, and Peacemaker for both. I think you can get 
all 3 in a box set. And actually, it's possible you may even have luck just 
getting all new litter stuff and using the Spirit Essences without making 
separate living/litter spaces. On a final note, when I had this situation, 
I had to put the litter box more in the open, so cat #1 could see cat #2 
coming, from a greater distance. Avoid the urge to tuck the box around a 
corner.
comments.author: procrastistamper

comments.text:
None of it makes it into the box, but that's a good question. I will try 
the petsmart product - why not? Maybe there's more than one issue, won't 
know until I try!

It's mostly a territory insecurity behavior, I believe. Cat #1 (best I can 
tell) only does this when I'm in the room. I'm pretty sure she's telling me 
she doesn't like being chased out of the box. I caught cat #2 ambushing cat 
#1 in the box yet again last night. Both see the vet regularly, both were 
fixed young-but-not-too-young, cat #2 gets many active play sessions per 
day (enough to wear me out and I'm a 20-something athlete), they eat on a 
very regular schedule and both are healthy weights, I'm going through 
catifying my house again and replacing/moving litter boxes again, I'm leash 
training cat #2 to go on walks (though we haven't made it outside yet, he's 
not really going for the harness), and I'm running out of ideas.

top_comment.text:
I'm not quite sure how to word the question for the answer that I'm 
seeking, but I'll do my best to make sense of it. 
My cat Poe makes a habit of following me to the bathroom. He will either 
just sit there and watch me do my business, or handle his own business 
simultaneously while he stares at me in a disturbing fashion. If I had to 
describe it, I would say that it's a very intent look. 
I suppose my question would be is this a normal behavior? It makes me 
uncomfortable, but I'm not sure how to redirect it. If I close the door and 
don't allow him to enter with me he will sit outside the door and cry out 
in an almost tormented fashion. Am I upsetting him? Because he started to 
spray around the apartment almost immediately after I began to do so. I've 
looked up many Youtube videos to no avail. 
I apologize if my post was too excessive. It's just such a weird issue I 
felt it needed a bit of explanation. Comments and advice would be 
wonderful. I need to break this habit. He has already ruined my couch in 
one of what I assume to be revenge attempts. I don't want to just peg him 
as an asshole and I don't want to have to lose him. My be won't put up with 
it much longer.﻿
top_comment.author: MaskedVoodoo Mindfunk

comments.text:
You are your cat's pride or community. Cats are very curious and if there 
is a member of their pride doing their business somewhere weird, they're 
going to want to know about it. This is very normal and a sort of "bonding" 
thing for your kitty. Naturally their pride members would be doing it 
around them, and since you are the "sole provider" of the pride (you feed 
him), it's weird that you're not marking your territory. He may find it 
comforting if you leave "smelly" personal items around the house like hair 
brushes, shoes etc.
comments.author: Emilia Kills

comments.text:
It did help though. I was quite worried that he was a bit, abnormal shall 
we say? Lol I mean the fact that he's weird is a given. I'm pretty sure my 
initial comment spelled that out in vivid colour. But it's good to know 
that other cats have the same habits. At first I thought that he was 
associating me using the restroom as being his potty time too. When he was 
super tiny he used to hate the bathroom and only go in when I or my bf 
would. So I've considered that he might loath the bathroom in general. 
Hopefully he answers back so I can make sure that my denying Poe access to 
the restroom while I'm occupying it isn't detrimental to him somehow on any 
level.
comments.author: MaskedVoodoo Mindfunk

comments.author: ILTK

comments.text:
+ILTK I do something similar. I have a big, deep rubbermade tote and fill 
the box probably 6-8 inches deep with clumping litter. It still doesn't get 
all of it, but it is dramatically reduced.
comments.author: jackybaby1999

comments.text:
Get a huuuuge rubbermaid/bedroller box with high sides they're pretty 
cheap. Now kitty can kick and dig since the litter can be deep and no 
litter goes over the sides no matter how much they kick and dig. I'm using 
old postal mail sorting boxes that I found, they're massive, like 5-6 times 
the size of the boxes in the video and takes 2-3 large bags of litter, no 
more litter kicked over the sides. All my cats love it. It can be accessed 
from all sides and the size means they don't feel trapped in a small box 
with a small opening + the depth of the litter means it's very easy to 
scoop and the pee won't make clumps that sticks to the bottom.
comments.author: ILTK

open but it's not a big deal now so I'll stick with covered to keep the 
litter in the box and not all over the house.

Why doesn't my kitty bury/cover his " business". I find myself doing it 
cause it smells so bad! ﻿
top_comment.author: Sheila Mueller

comments.text:
Cats leave their "business" uncovered as a sign to other cats that this is 
their territory.  When there are several cats in an area, the smell of the 
"business" is a sign to other cats.  I cover my cat's "business" as soon as 
I notice it.
comments.author: Jill Busl

comments.text:
+Stephanie S I had exactly the same situation. It was the first cat I ever 
had, and he only started leaving it uncovered once we got the second cat. 
The first cat NEVER went outside the box or had any other behavioral 
problems, so I'd just go cover it myself when he was done, and consider 
myself fortunate that this was the only consequence of introducing a new 
furry friend! For the odor, I found that once I started feeding my kitties 
a raw diet, there was almost none.
